awd_titl_txt: Human-Building Integration: Bio-Sensing Adaptive Environmental Control for Human Health and Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
1707068 (Choi). This research will develop an integrated human-centered framework for intelligent environmental control in a building. The physiological signals of the occupants, as well as their ambient environmental data, will be integrated by using sensing agents (such as wearable as well as remote sensors) and embedded environmental sensors in the building. This will enable bio-sensing-driven multi-criteria decisions for determining building thermal and lighting system controls that will potentially lower energy usage awhile improving occupant comfort. 

This human-centered approach will provide a framework that will 1) address sensor data processing and analysis challenges that are inherent in large and dynamic datasets generated from sensing agents; 2) develop methods for optimizing decisions and solutions to multiple-criteria problems pertaining to occupants' preferences; and 3) establish a human-centered control approach that is integrated with a conventional control system for building retrofits to enable real-time decision making and system optimization that will enhance energy efficient operations and occupants' comfort. Such a three-fold approach can lead to tailored building environmental control systems with the potential for dramatically improving the efficiency of a building's performance, increasing sustainability, and leveraging informatics technology that will improve the occupants' quality of life.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Most existing technology and research in the field of building performance management focuses on system-centered engineering solutions, which make users passive in the system control loop rather than allowing them to engage as a proactive parameter in the control mechanism. Inefficient energy usage could come from such passiveness, putting the building's occupants' environmental comfort and pleasure at risk. As a result, the primary goal of our study was to create an integrated human-centered framework for intelligent environmental control in buildings in order to improve the health, wellbeing, and environmental sustainability of building occupants.

Given the significance of human wellbeing and wellness in today's world, this project was timely and relevant in terms of demonstrating how to achieve human wellness in the built environment using advanced modern technologies like wearable sensors, smart sensing units, and computational data mining techniques.

This project established an innovative approach that integrates human-centered approaches with building environmental control systems focused on thermal and visual quality over a four-year period. The project team validated how to implement human-centered environmental control in offices/workplaces by resolving multiple-criteria issues related to occupants' environmental preferences and the building thermal and lighting performance, which have been frequently reported as a source of sick building syndrome issues in practice. Based on the use of expertise from multiple disciplines: Building Science, Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, Medicine, and Psychology, this interdisciplinary research resulted in innovative building environmental control systems that dramatically improve the occupants' quality of life, environmental satisfaction, and building performance. The research findings contribute to fundamental understanding on how to integrate human physiological principles and information in people's daily lives by filling integrative research gaps between those disciplines.

Due to the project's novelty in the building research discipline, it has been invited to a number of national and international events, seminars, and conferences, and the PI has been asked to develop a special issue based on the research theme of Human-Building Integration for a number of international journals. The project’s innovativeness motivated the interest of students and other researchers, and many of them requested an opportunity to participate in the project as a post-doc, visiting scholar, or volunteer student researcher. Furthermore, students from a variety of disciplines at the PI's institute approached the PI team to participate in the project, and they made substantial contributions to the research's technical function. The majority of the study results have been published in a variety of venues, which helped these next-generation scholars and professionals advance in their careers.

This effort was also well recognized by the industry. The PI team has collaborated with an industrial partner for the objective of technology transfer, and this endeavor is still ongoing. The intellectual outcomes and all efforts for improving border impacts will be continued in the next phase of the research, even after the project is over, in the form of multidisciplinary research with various academic and industry partners, as well as student/junior scholar engagement.
